{{Infobox Organization | name = NATO Munitions Safety Information Analysis Center
Centre d'information et d'analyse sur la sécurité des munitions de l'OTAN |image = MSIAC.gif | caption = | type = NATO project | headquarters = [[Bruxelles]], [[Belgium]] | membership_type = Member states, [[PfP-countries]], [[Contact nations]] | membership = {{Collapsible list|title=15 states|{{flagicon|Australia|size=15px}} [[Australia]]|{{flagicon|Belgium|size=15px}} [[Belgium]]|{{flagicon|Canada|size=15px}} [[Canada]]|{{flagicon|Finland|size=15px}} [[Finland]]|{{flagicon|France|size=15px}} [[France]]|{{flagicon|Germany|size=15px}} [[Germany]]|{{flagicon|Italy|size=15px}} [[Italy]]|{{flagicon|Netherlands|size=15px}} [[Netherlands]]|{{flagicon|Norway|size=15px}} [[Norway]]|{{flagicon|Spain|size=15px}} [[Spain]]|{{flagicon|Sweden|size=15px}} [[Sweden]]|{{flagicon|United Kingdom|size=15px}} [[United Kingdom]]|{{flagicon|United States|size=15px}} [[United States]]}} | language = [[English language|English]]
[[French language|French]] | leader_title = MSIAC Steering Committee Chairman | leader_name = Dr Brian Fuchs | leader_title2 = MSIAC Project Manager | leader_name2 = Dr Michael W. Sharp | formation = {{Start date|1991}}[http://www.msiac.nato.int/] MSIAC homepage | website = http://www.msiac.nato.int }} == Introduction == '''Munitions Safety Information Analysis Center''', also referred to as MSIAC, is a NATO project funded directly by its member nations, not all of which are [[NATO]] members. There are currently 15 member nations: [[Australia]], [[Belgium]], [[Canada]], [[Finland]], [[France]], [[Germany]], [[Italy]], [[Netherlands]], [[Norway]], [[Spain]], [[Sweden]], [[United Kingdom]], [[United States]], [[Poland]] and [[Republic of Korea]]. == History == === Pilot-Nato Insensitive Munition Information Center (Pilot-NIMIC) === On May 26, 1988 the NATO nations France, Netherlands, Norway, United Kingdom and the United States based on a Memorandum of Understanding decided to create Pilot-NIMIC (''NIMIC = NATO Insensitive Munitions Information Center''). The organization was intended to assist national and international programs to develop insensitive munitions (IM).''PNIMIC Newsletter'' '''1989''', ''1'', Johns Hopkins University Laurel Maryland, USA The idea for NIMIC was born at the NATO AC/310 "Workshop on Insensitive Munitions Information Exchange" in 1986 and was actively supported by the Chairman of AC/310, IGA M. Thévenin and Principal US Member of AC/310, Dr. R. Derr.''PNIMIC Newsletter'' '''1989''', ''3'', Johns Hopkins University Laurel Maryland, USA The founding of this organization was promoted by former NATO Group AC/310 (Safety and Suitability for Service of Munitions and Explosives) in an effort to support munitions developers located in NATO countries. The PILOT-NIMIC office was located at [[Applied Physics Laboratory]] (APL) of [[Johns Hopkins University]], Laurel, Maryland, USA. The initial team comprised a project manager and five technical specialists - basically the same structure MSIAC shows today (see below). Soon after its foundation Canada joined the project in late 1989. [[File:MSIAC 25 1.jpg|thumb|History of MSIAC]] [[File:MSIAC 25 2.jpg|thumb|MSIAC and АС/326 (CASG) experts on Celebrating 25 Years of MSIAC (15 december, 2016)]] [[File:MSIAC_25_HQ.jpg|thumb|Celebrating 25 Years of MSIAC (15 december, 2016))]] === NIMIC Move to Brussels and Growth === After its first successful two years of operation the project moved to NATO Headquarters Brussels and officially became NIMIC on May 1, 1991. Spain and Australia entered the project in 1994, Portugal and Italy became members in 1995. In 1998 Portugal decided to leave NIMIC. Denmark entered the project 1999 but left soon after in 2004. === Merger of AC/258 and AC/310 and Transition to MSIAC === In May 2003 the [[Conference of National Armament Directors]] (CNAD) Ammunition Safety Group (AC/326) (CASG) was formed by a merger of former AC/258 Group of Experts on the Safety Aspects of Transportation and Storage of Military Ammunition and Explosives and the former AC/310 Group of Safety and Suitability for Service of Munitions and Explosives.[http://www.nato.int/structur/AC/326/introduction.htm] CNAD Ammunition Safety Group (AC/326)Homepage With a given broader emphasis on Munitions Safety it was decided to modify NIMIC's scope to take this change into account. Hence its transition to Munitions Safety Information Analysis Center (MSIAC) began with the Pilot MSIAC phase in Spring 2003. The successful transition was accomplished by late 2004 and MSIAC was officially operational on December 15, 2004. Germany finally entered the project in 2005. [[Belgium]] entered MSIAC in 2015, [[Poland]] - in 2017 and [[Republic of Korea]] - in 2018. == Organization == The MSIAC Project Office consists of a steering committee, National Focal Point Officers (NFPO) and an Information Analysis Center (MSIAC). The steering committee is made up of one voting representative from each member nation and an elected chairman. It is responsible for implementing the Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) that established MSIAC and for developing its policy. This policy is carried out on a day-to-day basis by the MSIAC Project Manager. == Tasks == The '''NATO Munitions Safety Information Analysis Center''' (MSIAC) (''Centre d'information et d'analyse sur la sécurité des munitions de l'OTAN'' (CIASM) in French) provides technical consultancy services to its member nations in the area of munitions safety. Areas with which MSIAC is concerned include{{youtube|S68FkBBCNY8|MSIAC25: Celebrating 25 Years Helping Member Nations Improve Munitions Safety}} : * [[Energetic material]]s - [[high explosive]]s, [[gun propellant]]s, [[rocket propellant]]s and [[pyrotechnic]]s; * [[Warhead]] Technology – design, production, testing, terminal effects, fuzing systems; * [[Air propulsion|Propulsion]] Technology – design, production, testing, ignition/initiation systems; * [[Munition]]s Systems – weapon system integration, threat and hazard analysis, safety and suitability for service, demil and disposal; * Munitions [[Logistics]] – safety principles and regulations for transport and storage, hazard classification and risk analysis; * [[Material Sciences]] - understanding structural materials and their influence on safety and functionality of ammunition. Within these areas, MSIAC performs the following functions: *Develop the MSIAC internal database of technical information; *Provide technical advice; *Respond to inquiries from governmental agencies and industry of member nations; *Anticipate inquiries and prepare state-of-the-art reports to deal with them; *Organize technical lectures{{cite web |url=http://www.msiac.nato.int/newsletter/Q2_2008.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-03-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722012951/http://www.msiac.nato.int/newsletter/Q2_2008.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-22 |df= }} ''MSIAC Newsletter 2'' '''2008''' *Develop and distribute software tools and databases,;E.-C. Koch, EMC 3.8 - Energetic Materials Compendium - A Tool for Research, Development and Design, ''40th International Annual Conference of ICT'', 23–26 June, '''2009''', Karlsruhe, Germany, V-1.[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/272826559_EMC_4.0.2Energetic_Materials_Compendium_-A_Tool_for_Research__Development__Design] E. Lapébie, F. Grannec, P.-F. Péron, Modelling of Warhaed Response to Projectile Impact with TEMPER Software, ''40th International Annual Conference of ICT'', 23–26 June, '''2009''', Karlsruhe, Germany, P-116. *Organize Round Robin Tests;[http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/prep.200800201/abstract] R. M. Doherty, D. S. Watt, Relationship Between RDX Properties and Sensitivity, ''Propellants Explos. Pyrotech. 33'' '''2008''' 4 - 13. *Develop and maintain networks of experts, through the sponsorship of workshops and seminars and the creation of e-Working Groups. ==List of officials== {| class="wikitable" |+ '''Chairmen of the NIMIC & MSIAC Steering Committee''' |- ! # ! Name ! Country ! Duration |- | 1 | Dr. Ron '''Derr''' | {{flagcountry|USA}} | 1991–1998 |- | 2 | Anthony '''Melita''' | {{flagcountry|USA}} | 1998–2005 |- | 3 | CPT RAN Jacqui '''King''' | {{flagcountry|Australia}} | 2005–2008 |- | 4 | Dr. Jerry '''Ward''' | {{flagcountry|USA}} | 2009-2011 |- | 5 | GPCPT Wade '''Evans''' OBE | {{flagcountry|Australia}} | 2011–2014 |- | 6 | LtCol Tony '''Heron''' | {{flagcountry|Canada}} | 2014–2016 |- | 7 | Dr Brian '''Fuchs''' | {{flagcountry|USA}} | 2016– |- |} {| class="wikitable" |+ '''PNIMIC, NIMIC, & MSIAC Project Manager''' |- ! # ! Name ! Country ! Duration |- | 1 | Henry F. '''Hege''' | {{flagcountry|USA}} | 1989 |- | 2 | George M. '''Starken''' | {{flagcountry|USA}} | 1989 |- | 3 | Edward '''Daugherty''' | {{flagcountry|USA}} | 1990–1991 |- | 4 | GEN Marc '''Défourneaux''' | {{flagcountry|France}} | 1992–1995 |- | 5 | GEN Michel '''Thévenin''' | {{flagcountry|France}} | 1995–1998 |- | 6 | Dr. Peter '''Lee''' | {{flagcountry|UK}} | 1998–2002 |- | 7 | BGN Patrick '''Touzé''' | {{flagcountry|France}} | 2002–2010 |- | 8 | Roger L. '''Swanson''' | {{flagcountry|USA}} | 2010 – 2013 |- | 9 | Dr. Michael W. '''Sharp''' | {{flagcountry|UK}} | 2013 – |- |} == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:NATO agencies]] [[Category:Military science]] [[Category:Military technology]]

{{Infobox Observatory |name = Nottingham Weather Centre |background = |image = |caption = |organization = [[Met Office]] |code = |location = [[Watnall]], [[Nottinghamshire]], United Kingdom |coords = {{coord|53|00|20|N|1|15|06|W|type:landmark_region:GB|display=inline,title}} |altitude = {{convert|117|m|abbr=on|disp=or}} |weather = Average temperature: {{convert|9.8|C|F}}{{efn|Average temperature was calculated by finding the mean between the average annual maximum temperature and the average annual minimum temperature during the period of 1981–2010.<ref>[https://www.metoffice.gov.uk/public/weather/climate/gcrje93b8 Met Office] Retrieved 04 Apr 2018</ref>}} |established = 1941<ref>[http://artefacts.ceda.ac.uk/badc_datadocs/surface/station_lists/midas_stations.html] Retrieved 4 Apr 2018</ref> |closed = |website = |telescope1_name = |telescope1_type = |telescope2_name = |telescope2_type = | map_type = United Kingdom Nottinghamshire | map_caption = Shown in Nottinghamshire | map_relief = 1 }}
The '''Nottingham Weather Centre''' (also referred to '''Nottingham Watnall''') is a functioning [[observatory|observation]] and [[weather station]] located in [[Watnall]], [[Nottinghamshire]] in [[England]]. The weather station is located {{convert|5.6|mi|1|abbr=out}} from the city centre of [[Nottingham]], and is the closest weather station to Nottingham with observations.
The weather station was established in 1941<ref>[http://artefacts.ceda.ac.uk/badc_datadocs/surface/station_lists/midas_stations.html] Retrieved 4 Apr 2018</ref> and like many other weather stations in the United Kingdom, the recording of weather observations began in January 1960. The weather centre is currently being managed by the [[Met Office]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://eca.knmi.nl/indicesextremes/customquerytimeseriesplots.php?optionSelected=station&processtext1=Your+query+is+being+processed.+Please+wait...&countryselect=UNITED+KINGDOM%7Cgb&stationselect=NOTTINGHAM+WEATHER+CENTRE%5Bgb%5D%7C2118&categoryselect=All+categories%7C**&indexselect=All+indices%7C**&seasonselect=ANNUAL%7C0&processtext2=Your+query+is+being+processed.+Please+wait...|title=Watnall Time Series Plots|website=Eca.knmi.nl|accessdate=4 April 2018}}</ref>.
==Climate== {{For|extended climate data of the Nottingham Weather Centre|Nottingham#Climate}} As the weather station is located at a higher elevation of {{convert|117|m|abbr=on|disp=or}}, temperatures are usually cooler than the city centre of Nottingham and the [[Sutton Bonington]] weather station, as these locations are situated on a lower elevation.
During the period of 1981–2010, the Nottingham Weather Centre lies within [[hardiness zone|hardiness zone 9a]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://eca.knmi.nl/utils/calcdetail.php?seasonid=0&periodid=1981-2010&indexid=TNn&stationid=2118|title=Watnall Annual Average Minimum|website=Eca.knmi.nl |accessdate=4 April 2018}}</ref> and lies within the [[hardiness zone#American Horticultural Society heat zones|AHS heat zone 1]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://eca.knmi.nl/utils/calcdetail.php?seasonid=0&periodid=1981-2010&indexid=TXx&stationid=2118|title=Watnall Annual Average Maximum|website=Eca.knmi.nl|accessdate=4 April 2018}}</ref>. For the periods of 1961–1990 and 1971–2000 the station lied within the [[hardiness zone|hardiness zone 8b]], as the average annual minimum temperature was below {{convert|-6.7|C|F}} during those periods<ref>{{cite web |url=http://eca.knmi.nl/utils/calcdetail.php?seasonid=0&periodid=1971-2000&indexid=TXx&stationid=2118|title=Watnall Annual Average Minimum 1971-2000|website=Eca.knmi.nl|accessdate=4 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://eca.knmi.nl/utils/calcdetail.php?seasonid=0&periodid=1961-1990&indexid=TXx&stationid=2118|title=Watnall Annual Average Minimum 1961-1990|website=Eca.knmi.nl|accessdate=4 April 2018}}</ref>.
==References== {{reflist|group=lower-alpha}}
[[Category:Meteorological stations]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Nottinghamshire]] [[Category:Science and technology in Nottinghamshire]]

{{technical|date=March 2013}} When an [[atom]] has more than one [[electron]] there will be some [[electrostatic]] repulsion between those electrons. The amount of repulsion varies from atom to atom, depending upon the number and [[spin (physics)|spin]] of the electrons and the [[atomic orbital|orbital]]s they occupy. The total repulsion can be expressed in terms of three parameters ''A'', ''B'' and ''C'' which are known as the '''Racah parameters''' after [[Giulio Racah]], who first described them. They are generally obtained empirically from gas-phase [[spectroscopic]] studies of atoms.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ballhausen|first=C.J.|title=Molecular Electronic Structure of Transition Metal Complexes |year=1980|publisher=McGraw-Hill|isbn= 0070034958}}</ref>
They are often used in transition-metal chemistry to describe the repulsion energy associated with an electronic [[term symbol|term]]. For example, the interelectronic repulsion of a <sup>3</sup>P term is ''A'' + 7''B'', and of a <sup>3</sup>F term is ''A'' - 8''B'', and the difference between them is therefore 15''B''.
== Definition ==
The Racah parameters are defined as
<math> \begin{pmatrix} A \\ B\\ C\\ \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & -49\\ 0 & 1 & -5 \\ 0 & 0 & 35 \\ \end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} F_0 \\ F_2\\ F_4\\ \end{pmatrix} </math>
where <math>F_k</math> are [[Slater integrals]]
<math> \begin{pmatrix} F_0 \\ F_2\\ F_4\\ \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} F^0 \\ \frac{1}{49}F^2\\ \frac{1}{441}F^4\\ \end{pmatrix} </math>
and <math>F^k</math> are the [[Slater-Condon parameters]]
<math> F^k := \int_0^\infty r_1^2 dr_1 \int_0^\infty r_2^2 dr_2 R^2(r_1) R^2(r_2)\frac{r_<^k}{r_>^{k+1}} </math>
where <math>R(r)</math> is the normalized radial part of an electron [[Atomic orbital|orbital]], <math>r_> = \max\{r_1,r_2\}</math> and <math>r_< = \min\{r_1,r_2\}</math> <ref>{{cite book|last1=Sugano|first1=Satoru|last2=Tanabe|first2=Yukito|last3=Kamimura|first3=Hiroshi|title=Multiplets of Transition Metal Ions in Crystals|year=1970|publisher=Academic Press}}</ref>.
== See also == * [[Tanabe-Sugano diagram]] * [[Nephelauxetic effect]]
== References == {{reflist}} <!-- *{{cite journal |author=Junge L, Parlitz U |title=Phase synchronization of coupled ginzburg-landau equations |journal=Phys. Rev. E |volume=62 |issue=1 Pt A |pages=438–41 |year=2000 |month=July |pmid=11088478 |doi= 10.1103/physreve.62.438|url=}} -->
==External links== * [http://www.cond-mat.de/events/correl12/manuscripts/eder.pdf Multiplets in Transition Metal Ions] in E. Pavarini, E. Koch, F. Anders, and M. Jarrell (eds.): Correlated Electrons: From Models to Materials, Jülich 2012, {{ISBN|978-3-89336-796-2}}
[[Category:Coordination chemistry]] [[Category:Spectroscopy]]
{{physical-chemistry-stub}}

revision.comment: /* MS and Male Sex Hormones */clean up, replaced: Progress in brain research → Progress in Brain Research
revision.text:
'''Rhonda Renee Voskuhl''' is an American [[physician]], [[Scientist|research scientist]], and [[professor]]. She is a member of the Brain Research Institute (BRI) at the [[David Geffen School of Medicine at UCLA]] and is the director of its Multiple Sclerosis Program. Voskuhl has published numerous scientific articles in academic journals and has served in the role of [[principal investigator]] for several treatment trials investigating potential treatments for [[Multiple sclerosis|multiple sclerosis (MS)]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://people.healthsciences.ucla.edu/institution/personnel?personnel_id=9327|title=Faculty Database {{!}} David Geffen School of Medicine at UCLA|website=people.healthsciences.ucla.edu|access-date=2017-10-17}}</ref>
== Research ==
=== Approach and Research Model === Voskuhl has described her research as "bedside to bench to bedside", meaning observations made in clinical settings are used as a basis for the investigation of the relevant biological mechanisms of action. The information discovered is then applied in a clinical setting, typically through a drug therapy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.msconnection.org/Blog/February-2014/Sex-hormones-MS-An-interview-with-Dr-Rhonda-Voskuh|title=Sex hormones & MS: An interview with Dr. Rhonda Voskuhl|first=|date=14 Feb 2014|website=MS Connection|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=17 Oct 2017}}</ref>
=== MS and Female Sex Hormones === Due to well-documented differences in prevalence of MS in males and females,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Whitacre|first=Caroline C.|last2=Reingold|first2=Stephen C.|last3=O'Looney|first3=Patricia A.|last4=Blankenhorn|first4=Elizabeth|last5=Brinley|first5=Floyd|last6=Collier|first6=Elaine|last7=Duquette|first7=Pierre|last8=Fox|first8=Howard|last9=Giesser|first9=Barbara|date=1999-02-26|title=A Gender Gap in Autoimmunity: Task Force on Gender, Multiple Sclerosis and Autoimmunity*|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/283/5406/1277|journal=Science|language=en|volume=283|issue=5406|pages=1277–1278|doi=10.1126/science.283.5406.1277|issn=0036-8075|pmid=10084932}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pozzilli|first=C.|last2=Tomassini|first2=V.|last3=Marinelli|first3=F.|last4=Paolillo|first4=A.|last5=Gasperini|first5=C.|last6=Bastianello|first6=S.|date=2003-01-01|title=‘Gender gap’ in multiple sclerosis: magnetic resonance imaging evidence|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1046/j.1468-1331.2003.00519.x/abstract|journal=European Journal of Neurology|language=en|volume=10|issue=1|pages=95–97|doi=10.1046/j.1468-1331.2003.00519.x|issn=1468-1331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Harbo|first=Hanne F.|last2=Gold|first2=Ralf|last3=Tintoré|first3=Mar|date=Jul 2013|title=Sex and gender issues in multiple sclerosis|journal=Therapeutic Advances in Neurological Disorders|volume=6|issue=4|pages=237–248|doi=10.1177/1756285613488434|issn=1756-2856|pmc=3707353|pmid=23858327|via=}}</ref> significant research on the autoimmune condition has turned to the neuropreservative effects of sex hormones. Evidence of suppression of MS symptoms in pregnant women in the third trimester<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Confavreux|first=Christian|last2=Hutchinson|first2=Michael|last3=Hours|first3=Martine Marie|last4=Cortinovis-Tourniaire|first4=Patricia|last5=Moreau|first5=Thibault|last6=Group|first6=the Pregnancy in Multiple Sclerosis|date=1998-07-30|title=Rate of Pregnancy-Related Relapse in Multiple Sclerosis|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1056/NEJM199807303390501|journal=New England Journal of Medicine|volume=339|issue=5|pages=285–291|doi=10.1056/NEJM199807303390501|issn=0028-4793|pmid=9682040}}</ref> ultimately led to a focus on the female sex hormone estriol.
==== The Mouse Model: Experimental Autoimmune Encephalomyelitis (EAE) ==== In 2001, Voskuhl published an article outlining discrepancies in EAE between male and female mice; she noted that females were more susceptible to EAE, mirroring the sex-based difference in MS in humans. It was found that the neuroprotective effects of testosterone contributed most to this discrepancy in mice. However, this sex difference is reduced during late pregnancy in females, when estriol levels are significantly higher than other periods of life. Her article established high levels of estriol as a possible explanation for the reduction in EAE symptoms observed during late pregnancy.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Voskuhl|first=Rhonda R.|last2=Palaszynski|first2=Karen|date=2016-06-29|title=Sex Hormones in Experimental Autoimmune Encephalomyelitis: Implications for Multiple Sclerosis|url=https://doi.org/10.1177/107385840100700310|journal=The Neuroscientist|language=en|volume=7|issue=3|pages=258–270|doi=10.1177/107385840100700310}}</ref>
==== Estriol Treatment for Women with MS ==== In 2002, Voskuhl was part of the investigative team that found that treating non-pregnant women with 8 mg/day estriol helped to relieve symptoms, including lesion number and volume. Upon cessation of treatment, lesion number and volume returned to pre-treatment levels. After reinstituting treatment, lesion number and volume again decreased significantly. Cognitive ability, evaluated by the Paced Auditory Serial Addition Test (PASAT), also improved in those treated with estriol. In the authors' abstract, they indicated that this result warranted further experimentation through a placebo-controlled clinical trial.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sicotte|first=Nancy L.|last2=Liva|first2=Stephanie M.|last3=Klutch|first3=Rochelle|last4=Pfeiffer|first4=Paul|last5=Bouvier|first5=Seth|last6=Odesa|first6=Sylvia|last7=Wu|first7=T. C. Jackson|last8=Voskuhl|first8=Rhonda R.|date=2002-10-01|title=Treatment of multiple sclerosis with the pregnancy hormone estriol|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ana.10301/abstract|journal=Annals of Neurology|language=en|volume=52|issue=4|pages=421–428|doi=10.1002/ana.10301|issn=1531-8249}}</ref> This experiment was small, with only six women with relapse remitting MS (RRMS) and four women with secondary progressive MS (SPMS) finishing the trial. The authors noted that estriol generally improved symptoms in women with RRMS, but not in those with SPMS.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gold|first=Stefan M|last2=Voskuhl|first2=Rhonda R|date=2009-11-15|title=Estrogen Treatment in Multiple Sclerosis|journal=Journal of the Neurological Sciences|volume=286|issue=1-2|pages=99–103|doi=10.1016/j.jns.2009.05.028|issn=0022-510X|pmc=2760629|pmid=19539954}}</ref>
==== Molecular Basis for Estrogen's Neuroprotective Activity ==== In a 2011 research article, Voskuhl published data revealing that the estrogen receptor α (ERα) on [[astrocyte]]s, not [[neuron]]s, was responsible for the reduction of clinical EAE symptoms in mice. Using a gene knockout system [[Cre-Lox recombination|Cre-Lox]], the research team was able to remove ERα from neurons and in separate mice, remove ERα from astrocytes. It was found that the mice with ERα knocked out in astrocytes experienced an increase in clinical disease symptoms, macrophage and T-cell inflammation in the central nervous system, and axonal loss. These symptoms were not observed in those mice who had ERα removed from neurons.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Spence|first=Rory D.|last2=Hamby|first2=Mary E.|last3=Umeda|first3=Elizabeth|last4=Itoh|first4=Noriko|last5=Du|first5=Sienmi|last6=Wisdom|first6=Amy J.|last7=Cao|first7=Yuan|last8=Bondar|first8=Galyna|last9=Lam|first9=Jeannie|date=2011-05-24|title=Neuroprotection mediated through estrogen receptor-α in astrocytes|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|volume=108|issue=21|pages=8867–8872|doi=10.1073/pnas.1103833108|issn=0027-8424|pmc=3102368|pmid=21555578}}</ref>
==== Phase II Trial of Estriol as a Treatment for Women with RRMS ==== In 2016, the results of a [[Phase II trial|Phase II Trial]], in which Voskuhl participated, were released, detailing an experiment in which women with RRMS were treated daily with 8 mg estriol or placebo, combined with 20 mg injectable [[glatiramer acetate]] - an immunomodulator currently used to treat MS. It was found that women with the estriol treatment had significantly less relapses than the placebo group (0.25 relapses/year and 0.37 relapses/year, respectively), with similar amounts of serious adverse health events. The success of this trial convinced the authors to report that a [[Phase III trial|Phase III Trial]] was warranted.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Voskuhl|first=Rhonda R.|last2=Wang|first2=HeJing|last3=Wu|first3=T. C. Jackson|last4=Sicotte|first4=Nancy L.|last5=Nakamura|first5=Kunio|last6=Kurth|first6=Florian|last7=Itoh|first7=Noriko|last8=Bardens|first8=Jenny|last9=Bernard|first9=Jacqueline T.|date=January 2016|title=Estriol combined with glatiramer acetate for women with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis: a randomised, placebo-controlled, phase 2 trial|journal=The Lancet. Neurology|volume=15|issue=1|pages=35–46|doi=10.1016/S1474-4422(15)00322-1|issn=1474-4465|pmid=26621682}}</ref>
=== MS and Male Sex Hormones === In 2008, Voskuhl, together with Dr. Stefan Gold et al., published a study that revealed the effects of treating men with MS with a 10g gel containing 100 mg testosterone. Based upon the shift in cellular and chemical composition, particularly a decrease in IL-2 cell production, an increase in production growth factor TGFβ1, a decrease in CD4+ T cells, and an increase in NK (natural killer) cells, it was found that testosterone may play an important role in immunomodulation and neuroprotection.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gold|first=Stefan M|last2=Chalifoux|first2=Sara|last3=Giesser|first3=Barbara S|last4=Voskuhl|first4=Rhonda R|date=2008-07-31|title=Immune modulation and increased neurotrophic factor production in multiple sclerosis patients treated with testosterone|journal=Journal of Neuroinflammation|volume=5|pages=32|doi=10.1186/1742-2094-5-32|issn=1742-2094|pmc=2518142|pmid=18671877}}</ref>
In a 2009 review article discussing the effects of sex hormones on MS, Voskuhl and Gold noted that one small trial conducted by a research team headed by Dr. Nancy Sicotte<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sicotte|first=Nancy L.|last2=Giesser|first2=Barbara S.|last3=Tandon|first3=Vinita|last4=Klutch|first4=Ricki|last5=Steiner|first5=Barbara|last6=Drain|first6=Ann E.|last7=Shattuck|first7=David W.|last8=Hull|first8=Laura|last9=Wang|first9=He-Jing|date=May 2007|title=Testosterone treatment in multiple sclerosis: a pilot study|journal=Archives of Neurology|volume=64|issue=5|pages=683–688|doi=10.1001/archneur.64.5.683|issn=0003-9942|pmid=17502467}}</ref> suggested testosterone could be effective in preserving cognitive performance and reducing brain atrophy.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gold|first=Stefan M|last2=Voskuhl|first2=Rhonda R|date=2009|title=Estrogen and Testosterone Therapies in Multiple Sclerosis|journal=Progress in Brain Research|volume=175|pages=239–251|doi=10.1016/S0079-6123(09)17516-7|issn=0079-6123|pmc=2724009|pmid=19660660}}</ref> However, this trial yielded no significant effect on the formation of brain lesions.
== In Media ==
=== NPR Morning Edition === In 2014, Voskuhl participated in an interview discussing estriol as a potential treatment for women with MS. The article discussed how estriol was identified as a potential candidate for drug treatment, including an anecdote about Melissa Glasser, a woman who experienced a reduction in her MS symptoms during each of her four pregnancies.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2014/06/02/317355068/pregnancy-hormone-may-reduce-multiple-sclerosis-symptoms|title=Pregnancy Hormone May Reduce Multiple Sclerosis Symptoms|work=NPR.org|access-date=2017-11-24|language=en}}</ref>
=== NPR Berlin === In 2016, Voskuhl was quoted in an article addressing gender bias in scientific study; she noted that male and female mice had different disease progression in the animal MS model.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nprberlin.de/post/fix-gender-bias-animal-research-could-help-humans|title=A Fix For Gender-Bias In Animal Research Could Help Humans|access-date=2017-11-24|language=en}}</ref>
== References == <references />
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Voskuhl, Rhonda}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American molecular biologists]] [[Category:Multiple sclerosis]] [[Category:Women and science]] [[Category:Women medical researchers]] [[Category:Women molecular biologists]] [[Category:Women neurologists]] [[Category:Women physicians]] [[Category:Vanderbilt University School of Medicine alumni]] [[Category:Phillips University alumni]]

{{Speciesbox | image = | status = CR | status_system = IUCN3.1 | status_ref = <ref name=IUCN>{{IUCN2013.2| id = 9773| title = Heleophryne rosei| assessor = South African Frog Re-assessment Group (SA-FRoG)| assessor2 = IUCN SSC Amphibian Specialist Group| year = 2010| downloaded = 14 March 2014}}</ref> | taxon = Heleophryne rosei | authority = [[John Hewitt (herpetologist)|Hewitt]], 1925 | range_map = Heleophryne rosei distribution.png | synonyms = }}
The '''Rose's ghost frog''' or '''Table Mountain ghost frog''' ('''''Heleophryne rosei''''') is a species of [[frog]] in the [[Heleophrynidae]] family [[Endemism|endemic]] to [[South Africa]].<ref name=frost>{{cite web |url=http://research.amnh.org/vz/herpetology/amphibia/Amphibia/Anura/Heleophrynidae/Heleophryne/Heleophryne-rosei |title=''Heleophryne rosei'' Hewitt, 1925 |author=Frost, Darrel R. |year=2014 |work=Amphibian Species of the World: an Online Reference. Version 6.0 |publisher=American Museum of Natural History |accessdate=14 March 2014}}</ref> It is a medium-sized species with purple or brown blotches on a pale green background and large discs on its fingers and toes. It has a very restricted range, being only known from the slopes of parts of [[Table Mountain]]. The [[tadpole]]s live in permanent streams but these are in danger of drying up because of the establishment of [[pine]] plantations. Because of its small range and changes in its habitat, this frog is listed as [[critically endangered]] by the [[International Union for Conservation of Nature]].
==Description== This is a moderately sized frog, with the larger female up to {{convert|60|mm|abbr=on}} and the smaller male up to {{convert|50|mm|abbr=on}} in length. The coloration of adults is striking, often a pale green background with purple to brown blotches. The fingers and toes have large, triangular terminal discs. A rudimentary thumb is present as a distinct inner metacarpal tubercle. The feet are half webbed, with one phalanx of the fifth toe free of web. The tadpole has neither an upper nor lower jaw sheath, but up to 17 rows of posterior labial teeth. The tadpole also has a large oral disc and is able to climb up wet vertical rock faces.<ref name=EDGE>{{cite web |url=http://www.edgeofexistence.org/amphibians/species_info.php?id=561 |title=Table Mountain ghost frog (''Heleophryne rosei'') |author= |year= |work=EDGE of Existence programme |publisher=Zoological Society of London |accessdate=14 March 2014}}</ref>
==Distribution== This species is known only from the southern, eastern, and marginally western slopes of [[Table Mountain]] in [[Cape Town]].<ref name=EDGE/>
==Habitat== The typical habitat of this frog includes moist, forested gorges, with vertical rock faces to more exposed streams surrounded by dense marginal vegetation, the latter habitat usually found at higher altitudes. Tadpoles require year-round supply of water whereas adults can stray away from streams, even to be found in caves.<ref name=EDGE/>
==Behaviour== The frogs are found on rock ledges or up in vegetation at night, retreating under large rocks and in cracks of rocks during the day.
==Diet== These frogs eat a range of small insects and other forest arthropods.
==Reproduction== Breeding starts in November when the streams are low but the temperature is high. The male's secondary sexual characteristics include a number of small black spines on the outside surfaces of the forearms, on the back, and on the top of the back legs. The eggs have not been found, but in other species they are deposited under rocks in streams. The tadpoles develop for about 12 months.<ref name=EDGE/>
==Conservation status== This species is listed as [[critically endangered]] by the [[International Union for Conservation of Nature]] (IUCN)<ref name=IUCN/> and in the South African Red Data Book.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://adu.org.za/frog_atlas.php |title=Summary Data of the Frogs of South Africa, Lesotho and Swaziland |author=Animal Demography Unit, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town |year=2014 |work= |publisher= |accessdate=14 March 2014}}</ref> The population is small, geographically restricted, and threatened by the plantations of pines on the mountain that cause the streams to dry up.<ref name=IUCN/><ref name=EDGE/> Many of the streams historically populated by ''Heleophryne rosei'' were diverted during the 1900s in order to supply the newly built reservoirs on Table Mountain.
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
{{Taxonbar|from=Q2712058}}
[[Category:Heleophryne]] [[Category:Frogs of Africa]] [[Category:Endemic amphibians of South Africa]] [[Category:Natural history of Cape Town]] [[Category:Table Mountain]] [[Category:Critically endangered fauna of Africa]] [[Category:EDGE species]] [[Category:Amphibians described in 1925]] [[Category:Taxa named by John Hewitt (herpetologist)]] [[Category:Taxonomy articles created by Polbot]]

revision.text:
'''Soybean management practices''' in [[farming]] are the decisions a producer must make in order to raise a [[soybean]] [[crop]]. The type of [[tillage]], plant population, row spacing, and planting date are four major management decisions that soybean farmers must consider. How individual producers choose to handle each management application depends on their own farming circumstances.
==Tillage==
Tillage is defined in farming as the disturbance of [[soil]] in preparation for a crop. Tillage is usually done to warm the [[seed]] bed up, to help dry the seed bed out, to break up [[disease]], and to reduce early [[weed]] pressure. Tillage prior to planting adds cost per acre farmed and has not been shown to increase soybean yields significantly.{{citation needed|date=October 2010}}
“[[No till]]” is the practice of planting seed directly into the ground without disturbing the soil prior to planting. This practice eliminates the tillage pass, saving the farmer the associated costs. Planting no-till places seed directly into a cooler and wetter seed bed, which can slow [[germination]].<ref name="hoeft2000">Robert G. Hoeft, Emerson D. Nafziger, Richard R. Johnson, and Samuel R. Aldrich . Modern Corn and Soybean Production. '1st ed. Champaign, IL: MCSP Publications, 2000.</ref> This process is considered a good [[Conservation (ethic)|conservation]] practice because tilling disturbs the soil crust, causing [[erosion]]. The practice of no-till is currently on the rise among farmers in the midwestern United States.{{citation needed|date=October 2010}}
==Plant Population==
Plant population is the number of [[seeds]] planted in a given area. Population is usually expressed as plants or seeds per acre. Plant population is one of two major factors that determine canopy closure (when the plants cover the space in between the rows) and other yield components.<ref name="pedersen2008">Pedersen, Palle. "Soybean Production." Iowa State University Soybean Extension and Research Program. 4, January 2008. Iowa State University Extension. 20 Feb 2008 <http://extension.agron.iastate.edu/soybean/topicpage1.html>.</ref> A higher seed population will close the canopy faster and reduce soil moisture loss. A high plant population does not necessarily equal a high yield. The recommended seeding rate is 125,000 to 140,000 seeds per acre.<ref name="pedersen2008" /> The goal is to achieve a final stand of 100,000 plants per acre.<ref name="pedersen2008" /> Planting the extra seed gives the producer added insurance that each acre will attain a final stand of 100,000 plants.
==Row Spacing==
Row spacing is the second factor that determines canopy closure and yield components.<ref name="pedersen2008" /> Row spacing can either refer to the space between plants in the same row or the distance between two rows. Row spacing determines the degree of plant to plant competition.<ref name="pedersen2008" /> Rows planted closer together in a population will decrease the space between plants. Closer row widths increase plant to plant competition for [[nutrients]] and [[water]] but also increase [[sunlight]] use efficiency. According to former Iowa State University Soybean Extension Specialist Palle Pedersen, current recommendations are to plant rows that are less than 30" apart. This increases light interception and decreases [[weed]] competition.<ref name="pedersen2008" />
==Planting Date==
Planting date refers to the date that the seed is sown. This concept is of prime importance in growing soybeans because yields are strongly correlated with planting date. Data from [[Iowa State University]] shows that earlier planted soybeans tend to have higher yields than soybeans planted later in the growing season. Producers seeding early need to check that the seedbed is in the right conditions ([[temperature]], [[moisture]], [[nutrients]]) since planting into a sub-optimal seedbed will lose yield instead of gaining it.<ref name="pedersen2008" /> Other special considerations include soil pathogens, insect pressure, and the possibility of [[frost]]. [[Fungicide]] treatment and [[insecticide]] treatment are options used to help reduce the risk of soil [[pathogens]] and insect pressure.<ref name="hoeft2000" /> Knowing the chance of frost in a given area prior to planting helps determine how early seed can safely be sown.<ref name="pedersen2008" />
== See also ==
* [[Agronomy]] * [[Agricultural soil science]] * [[Agricultural science]] * [[Agricultural productivity]] * [[List of soybean diseases]]
==References==

page.title: Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs

revision.comment: Remove 1 stray access-date. ([[User:GreenC bot/Job 5|GreenC bot job #5]])
revision.text:
{{redirect|SICP}} {{refimprove|date=June 2011}} {{Infobox book |italic title = force | name = Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs | image = SICP cover.jpg | caption = Cover of the second edition | author = [[Harold Abelson]], [[Gerald Jay Sussman]], Julie Sussman | cover_artist = | country = | series = | subject = [[Computer programming]] | genre = [[Textbook]] | publisher = [[MIT Press]] | pub_date = 1985 (1st ed.), 1996 (2nd ed.) | media_type = | pages = 657 | isbn = 0-262-51087-1 | isbn_note = (2nd ed.) | oclc = | dewey = | congress = QA76.6 .A255 1996 | website = https://mitpress.mit.edu/sicp }}
'''''Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs''''' ('''''SICP''''') is a textbook aiming to teach the principles of computer programming, such as [[abstraction (computer science)|abstraction]] in programming, [[metalinguistic abstraction]], [[recursion]], [[interpreter (computing)|interpreters]], and [[modular programming]]. It is widely considered a classic text in [[computer science]],<ref>{{citation | url = http://grokcode.com/11/the-top-9-in-a-hackers-bookshelf/ |title= Grok code | contribution = The Top 9{{frac |1|2}} Books in a Hacker's Bookshelf |accessdate = 2010-10-23}}</ref> and is colloquially known as the '''wizard book''', due to the wizard on the jacket.<ref>{{Citation | contribution = Wizard Book | title = The New Hacker's Dictionary | edition = 2nd | year = 1993 | contribution-url = http://mitpress.mit.edu/sicp/}}.</ref> It was first published in 1985 by [[MIT Press]] and written by [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] (MIT) professors [[Harold Abelson]] and [[Gerald Jay Sussman]], with Julie Sussman. It was formerly used as the textbook of MIT introductory programming class and at other schools. Before SICP, the introductory courses were almost always filled with learning the details of some programming language, while SICP focuses on finding general patterns from specific problems and building software tools that embody each pattern.<ref>{{Citation | last = Harvey | first = B | year = 2011 | contribution-url = http://www.eecs.berkeley.edu/~bh/sicp.html | contribution = Why SICP matters? | title = The 150th anniversary of MIT | publisher = [[Boston Globe]]}}.</ref>
==Content== Using [[Scheme (programming language)|Scheme]], a dialect of the [[Lisp programming language]], the book explains core computer science concepts.
The book also introduces a practical implementation of the [[register machine]] concept, defining and developing an [[Assembly language#Assember|assembler]] for such a construct, which is used as a [[virtual machine]] for the implementation of interpreters and compilers in the book, and as a testbed for illustrating the implementation and effect of modifications to the evaluation mechanism. Working Scheme systems based on the design described in this book are quite common student projects.
== Characters == The book uses some fictional characters repeatedly: * Ben Bitdiddle. He considerably predates this class, having been created by Steve Ward for use in problem sets for its predecessor, 6.031, in the 1970s. He has since appeared in a large number of other locations, including other classes at MIT and other institutions.{{Citation needed|date= January 2012}} * Eva Lu Ator: the evaluator * Louis Reasoner: the loose reasoner * Alyssa P. Hacker: a Lisp hacker * Cy D. Fect: A "reformed C programmer". * Lem E. Tweakit: an irate user of Alyssa's interval arithmetic, enters p. 96.
== License ==
The book is licensed under a [[Creative Commons]] Attribution ShareAlike 4.0 License.<ref>{{Citation | title = SICP | publisher = MIT press | url = http://mitpress.mit.edu/sicp/}}.</ref>
== Coursework == The book was used as the textbook of MIT's old introductory programming class, 6.001.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://ocw.mit.edu/OcwWeb/Electrical-Engineering-and-Computer-Science/6-001Spring-2005/CourseHome/ | work = OpenCourseWare | title = Electrical Engineering and Computer Science | 6.001 Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs |date=Spring 2005 | publisher = MIT | accessdate =2011-06-28}}</ref> This class has been replaced by 6.0001,<ref>{{Citation|title=Catalog|url=http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=6.0001|contribution=6.0001|publisher=MIT}}.</ref> which uses [[Python (programming language)|Python]].<ref>{{Citation | first = Donald | last = Guy | quote = I talked to Professor Sussman on the phone... He said that he'd actually been trying to have 6.001 replaced for the last ten years (and I read somewhere that Professor Abelson was behind the move too). Understanding the principles is not essential for an introduction to the subject matter anymore. He sees 6.001 as obsolete | url = http://www.mitadmissions.org/topics/learning/coursework/the_end_of_an_era_1.shtml | title = MIT Admissions | type = blog comment | contribution = The End of an Era | accessdate = 2008-08-05}}.</ref> Other schools also made use of the book as a course textbook.<ref>{{cite web| first = Edward C | last = Martin | url= http://www.schemers.com/schools.html | title= Schools |publisher= Schemers |date = 2009-07-20 |accessdate= 2011-06-28}}</ref> The second edition ({{ISBN|0-262-51087-1}}) appeared in 1996. More recently it is used as the textbook of MIT's Large Scale Symbolic Systems class, 6.945.<ref>http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2016SP&Subject=6.945</ref>
==Reception== ''[[Byte (magazine)|Byte]]'' recommended SICP "for professional programmers who are really interested in their profession". The magazine stated that the book was not easy to read, but that it would expose experienced programmers to both old and new topics.<ref name="kilov198611">{{cite news | title= Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs | work=Byte | date=November 1986 | last =Kilov | first = Haim | page = 70}}</ref>
== Influence == SICP has been influential in computer science education, and a number of later books have been inspired by its style. * ''[[Structure and Interpretation of Classical Mechanics]] (SICM)'', another book by Gerald Jay Sussman that uses Scheme * ''[[How to Design Programs]] (HtDP)'', which intends to be a more accessible book for introductory Computer Science, and to address perceived incongruities in SICP * ''[[Essentials of Programming Languages]] (EoPL)'', a book for Programming Languages courses * ''[[Lisp in Small Pieces]] (LiSP)'', a book full of Scheme interpreters and compilers
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
== External links == * [http://mitpress.mit.edu/sicp/ Official site] including textbook in HTML * [http://groups.csail.mit.edu/mac/classes/6.001/abelson-sussman-lectures/ Video Lectures]
[[Category:1985 books]] [[Category:1996 books]] [[Category:Computer science books]] [[Category:Creative Commons-licensed books]] [[Category:Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] [[Category:Scheme (programming language)]] [[Category:Lisp (programming language)]]

revision.comment: Add a source link for one of the pioneers in this field
revision.text:
'''Ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy''' ('''UPS''') refers to the measurement of kinetic energy [[spectroscopy|spectra]] of [[photoelectric effect|photoelectrons]] emitted by molecules which have absorbed [[ultraviolet]] photons, in order to determine [[molecular orbital]] energies in the valence region.
==Basic theory== If [[Einstein]]'s photoelectric law is applied to a free molecule, the [[kinetic energy]] (<math> E_K</math>) of an emitted photoelectron is given by
:<math> E_K = h\nu - I\,</math>,
where ''h'' is [[Planck's constant]], ν is the frequency of the ionizing light, and I is an [[ionization energy]] for the formation of a singly charged ion in either the [[ground state]] or an [[excited state]]. According to [[Koopmans' theorem]], each such ionization energy may be identified with the energy of an occupied molecular orbital. The ground-state ion is formed by removal of an electron from the [[highest occupied molecular orbital]], while excited ions are formed by removal of an electron from a lower occupied orbital.
==History== Prior to 1960, virtually all measurements of photoelectron kinetic energies were for electrons emitted from metals and other solid surfaces. About 1956 [[Kai Siegbahn]] developed [[X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy]] (XPS) for surface chemical analysis. This method uses x-ray sources to study energy levels of atomic [[core electron]]s, and at the time had an energy resolution of about 1 eV ([[electronvolt]]).<ref>Carlson T.A., "Photoelectron and Auger Spectroscopy" (Plenum Press, 1975) {{ISBN|0-306-33901-3}}</ref>
The ultraviolet method (UPS) was pioneered by [[Feodor Ivanovich Vilesov|Feodor I. Vilesov]], a physicist at St. Petersburg (Leningrad) State University in Russia (USSR) in 1961 to study the photoelectron spectra of free molecules in the gas phase.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Vilesov|first1=F. I.|last2=Kurbatov|first2=B. L.|last3=Terenin|first3=A. N.| title=Electron Distribution Over Energies In Photoionization Of Aromatic Amines in Gaseous Phase|journal=Soviet Physics, Doklady|date=1961|volume=6|page=490|bibcode = 1961SPhD....6..490V}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Price|first1=W. C.|title=Photoelectron Spectroscopy|journal=Advances in Atomic and Molecular Physics|date=1974|volume=10|page=131|doi=10.1016/S0065-2199(08)60348-6|bibcode=1974AdAMP..10..131P}}</ref> The early experiments used monochromatized radiation from a hydrogen discharge and a retarding potential analizer to measure the photoelectron energies. The PES was further developed by [[David W. Turner]], a physical chemist at [[Imperial College]] in London and then at [[Oxford University]], in a series of publications from 1962 to 1967.<ref>Rabalais J.W. "Principles of Ultraviolet Photoelectron Spectroscopy" (Wiley 1977) {{ISBN|0-471-70285-4}}</ref><ref>Turner D. W. Molecular Photoelectron Spectroscopy (Wiley, 1970)</ref> As a photon source, he used a [[helium]] discharge lamp which emits a wavelength of 58.4 nm (corresponding to an energy of 21.2 eV) in the vacuum ultraviolet region. With this source Turner's group obtained an energy resolution of 0.02 eV. Turner referred to the method as "molecular photoelectron spectroscopy", now usually "Ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy" or UPS. As compared to XPS, UPS is limited to energy levels of [[valence electrons]], but measures them more accurately. After 1967 commercial UPS spectrometers became available.<ref>Baker A.D. and Betteridge D. "Photoelectron Spectroscopy. Chemical and Analytical Aspects." (Pergamon Press 1972) p.ix</ref>
==Application== The UPS measures experimental [[molecular orbital]] energies for comparison with theoretical values from [[quantum chemistry]], which was also extensively developed in the 1960s. The photoelectron spectrum of a molecule contains a series of peaks each corresponding to one valence-region molecular orbital energy level. Also, the high resolution allowed the observation of fine structure due to [[vibrational spectroscopy|vibrational levels]] of the molecular ion, which facilitates the assignment of peaks to bonding, nonbonding or antibonding molecular orbitals.
The method was later extended to the study of solid surfaces where it is usually described as [[photoemission spectroscopy]] (PES). It is particularly sensitive to the surface region (to 10 nm depth), due to the short range of the emitted photoelectrons (compared to X-rays). It is therefore used to study [[Adsorption|adsorbed]] species and their binding to the surface, as well as their orientation on the surface.<ref>Peter W. Atkins and Julio de Paula "Physical Chemistry" (Seventh edition, W.H.Freeman, 2002), p.980 {{ISBN|0-7167-3539-3}}</ref>
A useful result from characterization of solids by UPS is the determination of the [[work function]] of the material. An example of this determination is given by Park et al.<ref>Y. Park et al., Appl. Phys. Lett 68(19), 2699-2701 (1996) Work function of indium tin oxide transparent conductor measured by photoelectron spectroscopy</ref> Briefly, the full width of the photoelectron spectrum (from the highest kinetic energy/lowest binding energy point to the low kinetic energy cutoff) is measured and subtracted from the photon energy of the exciting radiation, and the difference is the work function. Often, the sample is electrically biased negative to separate the low energy cutoff from the spectrometer response.
===Gas discharge lines=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Gas !! Emission Line !! Energy (eV) !! Wavelength (nm) !! Relative Intensity (%) |- | H || Lyman α || 10.20 || 121.57 || 100 |- | || Lyman β || 12.09 || 102.57 || 10 |- | He || 1 α || 21.22 || 58.43 || 100 |- | || 1 β|| 23.09 || 53.70 || approx 1.5 |- | || 1 γ || 23.74 || 52.22 || 0.5 |- | || 2 α || 40.81 || 30.38 || 100 |- | || 2 β || 48.37 || 25.63 || <10 |- | || 2 γ || 51.02 || 24.30 || negligible |- | Ne || 1 α || 16.67 || 74.37 || 15 |- | || 1 α || 16.85 || 73.62 || 100 |- | || 1 β || 19.69 || 62.97 || < 1 |- | || 1 β || 19.78 || 62.68 || < 1 |- | || 2 α|| 26.81 || 46.24 || 100 |- | || 2 α|| 26.91 || 46.07 || 100 |- | || 2 β || 27.69 || 44.79 || 20 |- | || 2 β || 27.76 || 44.66 || 20 |- | || 2 β || 27.78 || 44.63 || 20 |- | || 2 β || 27.86 || 44.51 || 20 |- | || 2 γ || 30.45 || 40.71 || 20 |- | || 2 γ || 30.55 || 40.58 || 20 |- | Ar || 1 || 11.62 || 106.70 || 100 |- | || 1 || 11.83 || 104.80 || 50 |- | || 2 || 13.30 || 93.22 || 30 |- | || 2 || 13.48 || 91.84 || 15 |}
==Outlook== UPS has seen a considerable revival with the increasing availability of [[Synchrotron light source|synchrotron light sources]] which provide a wide range of monochromatic photon energies.
==See also== *[[Angle resolved photoemission spectroscopy]] ARPES *[[Photoelectron photoion coincidence spectroscopy]] PEPICO *Time-resolved [[two-photon photoelectron spectroscopy]]
==References== {{reflist}}

page.title: William Wyse Professor of Social Anthropology

revision.comment: /* List of William Wyse Professors of Social Anthropology */
revision.text:
The '''William Wyse Professorship of Social Anthropology''' is a [[list of professorships at the University of Cambridge|professorship]] in [[social anthropology]] at the [[University of Cambridge]]. It was founded on 18 June 1932 and endowed partly with the support of [[Trinity College, Cambridge|Trinity College]] from money bequeathed to them by [[William Wyse]], formerly Fellow and Honorary Fellow of Trinity.<ref name = "Venn">[http://venn.csi.cam.ac.uk/ACAD/lists/aciff.html Venn database of Cambridge University offices and officers]</ref>
The professorship is assigned to the [[Faculty (division)|Faculty]] of [[Archaeology]] and [[Anthropology]].<ref name="Venn"/>
== List of William Wyse Professors of Social Anthropology== * 1932–1937 – [[Thomas Callan Hodson]]<ref name = "Venn" /> * 1937–1950 – [[John Henry Hutton]]<ref name = "Venn" /> * 1950–1973 – [[Meyer Fortes]]<ref name = "Venn" /> * 1973–1984 – [[Jack Goody]]<ref name = "Venn" /> * 1984–1992 – [[Ernest André Gellner]]<ref name = "Venn" /> * 1993–2008 – [[Marilyn Strathern]]<ref name = "Venn" /> * 2008–2014 – [[Henrietta Moore]] * since 2016 – [http://www.socanth.cam.ac.uk/directory/professor-james-laidlaw James Laidlaw]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.socanth.cam.ac.uk/about-us/news/2016-06-16-prof-laidlaw-appointed-william-wyse-professor|title=Professor James Laidlaw appointed as William Wyse Professor of Social Anthropology — Division of Social Anthropology|last=dcs43@cam.ac.uk|website=www.socanth.cam.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-07-26}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
{{anthropology-stub}} [[Category:Professorships at the University of Cambridge|Wyse]] [[Category:Professorships in anthropology]] [[Category:1932 establishments in England|Wyse]]
